instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.CPU_VR_EN: What is CPU_VR_EN? CPU_VR_EN is an enable signal for CPU VCORE that is present when it is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. ALL_SYS_PWRGD, PM_RSMRST_L, PM_SLP_SUS_L, and PM_SLP_S3_L are necessary prerequisites for CPU_VR_EN to be present. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No CPU Vcore
threads.message:
Hi,

I received this board. It was liquid damaged 
I don't know where exactly, because it was cleaned before I received it.

Corrosion:
Around LVDS
KB backlight connector
J6100 - I removed it
<CHIP>U7200</CHIP> - some corrosion next to it.

I cleaned the board.

The board goes to S0 state, but CPU Vcore does not present.
Missing <SIGNAL>CPU_VR_EN</SIGNAL>.

<SIGNAL>PPVMEMIO_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> 1.205V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> is present.

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 3.3V

Y1905 - oscillates
L7630 - 1.05V
PCH slowly gets warm

<CHIP>U7200</CHIP> powers on as far there are <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0_CPUVR_VIN</SIGNAL>.

Should I just change <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> or is there something I'm missing?

Thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No CPU Vcore
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No CPU Vcore
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No CPU Vcore
threads.message: Hmm, that does mean that <SIGNAL>CPU_VR_ON</SIGNAL> must be there or there must have been a pulse there. <RESISTOR>R7201</RESISTOR>/2 and traces are suspect

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No CPU Vcore
threads.message:
I rechecked <RESISTOR>R7201</RESISTOR>/2 and everything looks fine there. I've the right voltages on them.
I checked <SIGNAL>CPU_VR_EN</SIGNAL> if there is any pulse on that line, but nothing at all.
Checked the resistance on <SIGNAL>VR_ON</SIGNAL> again and it's open, so there is no short.

I'm trying to figure out what needs to get that signal.
Looks like it comes from the CPU.
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> high and <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL> is also present. Is that possible that trace damaged?

I checked <RESISTOR>R1955</RESISTOR> also. No pulses on it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No CPU Vcore
threads.message:
It could be anything. The CPU needs to be alive to enable the <SIGNAL>VR_ON</SIGNAL>. Could be dead CPU or corrosion under SMC/CPU.
It could be <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> but it would be my last suspect.
